narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not only did I learn to write in a more formal journalistic style, but I found that my commitment to conciseness, simplicity, and streamlined arguments has benefitted my academic writing as well. I learned a lot about how charter schools operate, what it's like to cover the DoE, and got to hear from and speak with a number of incredible education journalists working in the field.
Issues in education, how to do good journalism.

I developed a much deeper understanding of education policy in general, and I loved applying that knowledge to education journalism more specifically. I would also say that this course broadened my understanding of reporting of a 'bread and butter' topic like education and reframed it as a more experimental subject in my mind.
Learned about various facets of education through a journalistic lens (reading and discussing journalism), and practiced writing journalism articles.
I gained a good understanding of what it looks like to work in news, how to write succinctly, how to write longer-form pieces of journalism, and how to mix creative writing with news.
I learned all about journalism. I had no experience before, and I improved my writing SO MUCH through Professor Karr's feedback!
How to write for a publication
I learned a lot about modern education debates and the way they are portrayed in the media.

Great combo of journalism nuts-and-bolts combined with in-depth dives into topics across education news in the US. Loads of interesting speakers with great insights into a journalism career generally and their specific work experience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Great readings and fantastic discussions (Karr asks great questions, always comes prepared, and guides incredible conversations with guest speakers), challenging but manageable assignments and deadlines, wonderful feedback and revisions. The readings were super interesting. 

Additionally, Karr is often brutal but has a huge commitment to making sure that you succeed.

Strengths - good group of students, thorough feedback from professor on writing
Weaknesses - work comes in spurts, sometimes heavier workload sometimes lighter workload.

The assignments were great, as was the peer editing process. We could have discussed the readings more in seminars, as I enjoyed doing them outside of class. To incentivize people doing the readings, fewer readings could be assigned so we could go in depth on what we do tackle.
Consistent and timely feedback from Prof. Karr on assignments, explored topics that I wouldn't have otherwise.

The course was good in its very defined, predictable structurewe always wrote rough drafts, submitted them, and then worked on our final drafts based on professor and peer edits. This was a good format, as it allowed me to see how I was progressing in the course, and the peer/professor edits were inevitably great. The class setting was not as welcoming as other zoom seminars courses I attended, though this was at least in part bc of the virtual format.

Strengths: Real journalism experience. We actually got to choose our own topics for each paper (an op-ed, explanatory article, and long-form feature) and then interviewed experts.
Weaknesses: Lack of rubric!

Professor Karr is very attentive and we took time to workshop each student's ideas and pieces before we wrote final drafts, so those were all strengths. I think the only issue I had with the class is that I would have preferred we read more local journalism and fewer New York Times pieces, because while I respect the Times and its work, other voices would have been appreciated.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having a virtual TA (to help out with Zoom) helped streamline what I'm sure might have been a technological SNAFU. Everything ran very smoothly (shoutout to Abby!).

I thought there was a good blend of learning about how COVID-19 impacts education without letting that be the sole focus of the course. After all, we all lived the pandemic, so a bit of an escape was appreciated.
Virtual discussions were a bit more challenging than usual in-person, but still worked well in my opinion.
The break out rooms were very successful, as was editing our peer's pieces via google-doc. All in all it worked well, and I don't have any suggestions.

Since this was a 2 hour seminar, it could be difficult at times to fully focus. I think two hour seminars should be reserved for in-person teaching, and that online maybe it should be broken up into two days. But we did get a 5 minute break to help with the fatigue!
We used Zoom for seminar and for office hours. In-person classes would have been preferable, but I don't think the mode of learning could have been improved in any way given the circumstances.

Meeting more than once a week would be helpful, since I assume the 2hr slot was in place for travel to New Haven. But the content is so interesting and there is a wide variety of readings per lesson that could be better addressed with a few days to acts as buffer for thinking instead of the 5 minute break to mitigate Zoom fatigue in the middle of the two hours.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you want to learn about education, ed journalism, learn how to write in a journalistic style (OR WRITE BETTER IN GENERAL). You will get a wonderful opportunity to research subjects of your choosing, receive great feedback, and build your skills as a writer. Especially with interviews and readings, the class may require more dedication than some other classes, but much of that is dependent on how much effort you want to put into it.
Yes if you like journalism and have an interest in education. You'll become a better writer and finish the class with publishable pieces of journalism.
Yes! Especially if they are interested in education, journalism, or both. They also need to want to improve their writing, or else the feedback will be frustrating.
Yes! Was interesting and made me think deeply about education in our current society.

I would recommend the course to students who want  a good inside look into the world of journalism because they are interested in journalism, or to students who are interested in education studies. I would not recommend the course to students who are interested in writing and see the course as a way to flesh-out their writing skillsit teaches more about the thinking, story-chasing, and knowledge behind education reporting than the writing itself.

Yes. If you've never done journalism before, this is a GREAT way to start. The education beat itself is very lively, and it was amazing to hear from prominent education journalists and authors about their own experiences.
If you're interested in journalism or education, absolutely.
